awd_titl_txt: Membrane and Monolith Enzyme Reactors for Proteolysis After Capillary Electrophoresis to Enhance Detection of Proteoforms
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Merlin Bruening and his group at the University of Notre Dame are working to develop a new method to characterize small changes in the composition of proteins - key elements in the chemistry of life.  Subtle differences in composition can have large impacts on protein function (or malfunction) in cells and organisms, even when the protein variants are "coded" by the same gene.  A standard approach to this important problem is to digest proteins (break them into smaller, characteristic constituents known as peptides) and then identify them by separation and analysis of the resulting peptides.  This can lead to misidentifications (false positives and false negatives), especially when the structural differences are minor and/or the protein sample is complex.  The Bruening approach seeks to reduce these misidentifications by preceding digestion with a high-resolution separation of the intact proteins, thereby presenting for simultaneous analysis all the peptides associated with a given protein.  The approach requires thorough but rapid digestion - a key challenge and opportunity.  In the long run, the insights derived should enhance understanding of phenomena like the development of drug resistance by organisms such as the malaria parasite.  Dr. Bruening and his students are sharing insights about this effort at the interface between chemistry and biology through hosting high school students from underrepresented groups in their lab, and through outreach to school teachers.

Bottom-up proteomics is a powerful technique for identifying proteins via proteolysis, peptide separation, tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS), and comparison of mass spectra to the predictions derived from a protein database. However, because this strategy often gives low protein sequence coverage, proteoform identification, which may depend on detecting a specific peptide, is challenging.  To address this problem, the Bruening group is developing in-line digestion of proteins separated using capillary zone electrophoresis (CZE). Capillaries containing terminal enzyme-modified membranes or monoliths are being designed to enable digestion just prior to electrospray ionization MS/MS analysis. Thus, the MS/MS spectra of all the proteolytic peptides from a given protein will appear in a narrow time window.  Creation of a time-bin criterion will help to decrease both false-positive and false-negative peptide identifications, particularly for proteoforms.  Test applications include detection of proteoforms in model systems such as protein mixtures and histone variants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This research aimed to develop rapid digestion of separated proteins to enhance identification of these proteins and their various proteoforms. Identification of proteoforms is significant because the differences in protein-protein interactions for two proteoforms may differ greatly. In particular, the work aimed to digest and analyze proteins separated in capillary electrophoresis or gel electrophoresis. Due to the high concentration of immobilized enzymes, digestion can occur in seconds during rapid flow through enzyme-containing membranes.

This work showed that protease-containing membranes in spin columns enable digestion of therapeutic proteins (Trastuzumab and erythropoietin) or a viral protein (SARS-CoV-2 Receptor Binding Domain) in ~30 sec. Site-specific glycan identification was similar after in-solution and in-membrane digestion, and limited in-membrane digestion enhanced the identification of high-mannose glycans in Trastuzumab. Importantly, in-membrane digestion takes only ~30 seconds, whereas in-solution digestion usually occurs overnight. Site-specific glycan identification is important because glycosylation plays a pivotal role in the bioactivity of proteins, including the infectivity of viral proteins.

Because membranes rapidly digest proteins, this research also examined membrane-based digestion for analysis of proteins separated using gel or capillary electrophoresis. In-membrane proteolysis digested proteins during their electromigration from an electrophoretic gel through the enzyme-containing membrane to a capture substrate. Cutting the capture substrate in pieces enabled spatially resolved analysis of the digested proteins. Electroblotting of a gel-separated Escherichia coli (E. coli) cell lysate through a digestion membrane enabled identification of nearly 1500 proteins. Moreover, this procedure required four hours of total sample preparation and resulted in only 13% fewer protein identifications than in-gel digestion, which can take 24 h. Compared to traditional electroblotting and subsequent protein digestion on a capture membrane, adding a trypsin membrane to the electroblot increased the number of protein identifications by 22%. Thus, electroblotting with digestion can provide a convenient means to identify separated proteins. 

This research also employed pepsin-containing membranes to digest proteins online after a capillary electrophoresis (CE) separation and prior to tandem mass spectrometry. Proteolysis after the separation allowed the peptides from a given protein to enter the mass spectrometer in a single plug. Thus, migration time can serve as an additional criterion for confirming the identification of a peptide. The membrane resides in a sheath-flow electrospray ionization (ESI) source to enable digestion immediately before spray into the mass spectrometer, thus limiting separation of the digested peptides. Using the same membrane, digestion occurred reproducibly during 20 consecutive CE analyses performed over a 10-h period. Additionally, after separating a mixture of six unreduced proteins with CE, online digestion facilitated protein identification with at least 2 identifiable peptides for all the proteins. Sequence coverages were >75% for myoglobin and carbonic anhydrase II but lower for proteins containing disulfide bonds. Development of methods for efficient separation of reduced proteins or identification of cross-linked peptides should enhance sequence coverages for proteins with disulfide bonds. Migration times for the peptides identified from a specific protein differed by <~30 s, which allowed for rejection of some spurious peptide identifications.

Broader Impacts

This work developed new tools to identify proteins and their modifications.  Such identifications are important because the modification of proteins is often vital to their function. As part of the project, five graduate students, six undergraduate students, and two high school students gained important research experience.  Seven of these students are women or minorities.  Four graduating PhD students took jobs in the pharmaceutical industry based on their research expertise. The group presented a two-day "Teachers as Scholars" workshop to give teachers hands-on experience in analytical chemistry, including making calibration curves and performing and interpreting mass spectrometry.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2023
Modified by: Merlin L Bruening
